description: From Middle English tete, from Old French tete (“teat”) (compare French tette), from Frankish *tittā, *tittō, from Proto-Germanic *tittaz (“teat; nipple; breast”), ultimately of expressive origin. Compare Old High German zizza ("teat"; modern German Zitze), whence also Italian zizza (“teat”).
It heavily displaced Old English titt, a cognate of the same origin, which survives as tit, but in more vulgar use. Compare Dutch tiet and German Zitze (“teat”).

entries.meaning: (anatomy) The projection of a mammary gland from which, on female mammals, milk is secreted.
examples: Synonyms: tit (now vulgar), pap, nipple, dug

entries.meaning: Something resembling a teat, such as a small protuberance or nozzle.
An artificial nipple used for bottle-feeding infants.
